SENT.plain: The present report describes a case of right atrial thrombus in an active 49-year-old man with a primary antiphospholipid syndrome
In 1984, the patient was admitted for autoimmune hemolytic anemia; during the hospitalization it was diagnosed a chronic hepatitis B
In July 1991, the patient had fever, mild jaundice, splenomegaly and pancytopenia; a diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia was made but it was not subsequently confirmed
Interferon therapy was started and the patient's clinical course mildly improved
However, over the same year, he experienced again a clinical deterioration
Bone marrow biopsy revealed mielodisplastic syndrome
Necrotizing vasculitis with granulomatosis was diagnosed
The patient's condition improved after splenectomy
Repeated laboratory tests showed positivity for antiphospholipid antibodies
Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography demonstrated the presence of a right atrial thrombus, confirmed by nuclear magnetic resonance
The patient was started on long-term anticoagulant therapy, that resulted effective in reducing thrombus size
